newsitem.title: MEXICO: Salinas y Rocha up on sale rumors.
newsitem.headline: Salinas y Rocha up on sale rumors.

text.p: Shares of Mexican retail company Grupo Salinas y Rocha were sharply higher on the Bolsa in late trade Thursday on rumors the debt-strapped firm plans to sell some of its units, traders said.
Salinas y Rocha's benchmark L shares were up 21.21 percent to 80 centavos on the Mexican Stock Exchange, although traders noted volume was thin.
The company's shares have led the percentage gainers on the bourse for the past four sessions in a row.
"There is a rumor the company will sell assets shortly and that would reduce its debt significantly," one trader said.

"For about two years, the company has had plans to sell some of its assets and now would be a good time to do it because of the favorable expectations in the retail sector this year," said Christine Aimar, a retail analyst at Deutche Morgan Grenfell.
Analysts said the company might sell its department stores division and some real estate holdings, but keep its home furnishings unit known as Optima.
Company officials at Salinas y Rocha would not comment on the rumors.

"The company's silence on the matter makes me think whatever deal they are working on will be concluded soon," said another Mexico City analyst. Dealers and analysts did not know who the potential buyer might be.

Salinas y Rocha was hard hit by the 1994 peso crash. The company unveiled a plan to restructure some $450 million in debt. The company specializes in home furnishings and has 137 outlets in 65 cities.
